system:
You are a Text-to-SQL intelligence and one of your sub-tasks is to understand a natural language processing question posed by a user and help me extract the exact entities, relationships, intents, reasoning types, values, units, tables and fields to be used for the question. Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Assuming all printing tasks use A4 paper (210mm × 297mm, 80g/m²), group statistics by paper size to calculate the total paper mass consumed for each size of printing task (unit: kilogram)?
user:
The database information is as follows:First: printer database has consumables, maintenance_logs, manufacturers, print_jobs, printers, users tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The consumables table has Consumable_ID, Printer_ID, Type, Model, Capacity, Current_Level, Last_Replacement_Date, Next_Replacement_Date, Cost columns, and Consumable_ID is primary_key.
2 The maintenance_logs table has Maintenance_ID, Printer_ID, Maintenance_Date, Maintenance_Type, Description, Cost, Technician, Next_Maintenance_Date columns, and Maintenance_ID is primary_key.
3 The manufacturers table has Manufacturer_ID, Name, Country, Founded_Year, Revenue, Employee_Count, Market_Cap, Production_Volume_Total, R&D_Spending, Profit_Margin, Website, Headquarters columns, and Manufacturer_ID is primary_key.
4 The print_jobs table has Job_ID, Printer_ID, User_ID, Job_Date, Document_Name, Page_Count, Color_Usage, Paper_Size, Duplex, Status columns, and Job_ID is primary_key.
5 The printers table has Printer_ID, Manufacturer_ID, Model, Year, Type, Color_Support, Max_Resolution, Print_Speed, Paper_Size_Support, Tray_Capacity, Weight, Power_Consumption, Installation_Date, Location, IP_Address columns, and Printer_ID is primary_key.
6 The users table has User_ID, Name, Email, Phone, Department, Role columns, and User_ID is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
consumables.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
maintenance_logs.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
print_jobs.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
printers.Manufacturer_ID to manufacturers.Manufacturer_ID.
print_jobs.User_ID to users.User_ID.
assistant:
{
  "entities": ["A4 paper size (210mm × 297mm)", "80g/m² paper weight"],
  "relations": ["paper_size_to_mass (Paper_Size → mass_per_page)", "group_by_paper_size (Paper_Size → total_mass)"],
  "intent": "calculate_total_paper_mass_by_size",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [210, 297, 80],
  "units": {
    "dimensions": "mm (converted to m² for calculation)",
    "paper_weight": "g/m²",
    "mass_output": "kg (grams/1000)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["print_jobs"],
  "required_fields": [
    "print_jobs.Paper_Size", 
    "print_jobs.Page_Count"
  ]
}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Calculate the total electrical energy (in kilowatt-hours) required for a certain laser printer to operate continuously at maximum resolution for 24 hours, given that its power consumption is 800 watts, with an additional 200 watts consumed during the 15-minute warm-up phase.
user:
The database information is as follows:First: printer database has consumables, maintenance_logs, manufacturers, print_jobs, printers, users tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The consumables table has Consumable_ID, Printer_ID, Type, Model, Capacity, Current_Level, Last_Replacement_Date, Next_Replacement_Date, Cost columns, and Consumable_ID is primary_key.
2 The maintenance_logs table has Maintenance_ID, Printer_ID, Maintenance_Date, Maintenance_Type, Description, Cost, Technician, Next_Maintenance_Date columns, and Maintenance_ID is primary_key.
3 The manufacturers table has Manufacturer_ID, Name, Country, Founded_Year, Revenue, Employee_Count, Market_Cap, Production_Volume_Total, R&D_Spending, Profit_Margin, Website, Headquarters columns, and Manufacturer_ID is primary_key.
4 The print_jobs table has Job_ID, Printer_ID, User_ID, Job_Date, Document_Name, Page_Count, Color_Usage, Paper_Size, Duplex, Status columns, and Job_ID is primary_key.
5 The printers table has Printer_ID, Manufacturer_ID, Model, Year, Type, Color_Support, Max_Resolution, Print_Speed, Paper_Size_Support, Tray_Capacity, Weight, Power_Consumption, Installation_Date, Location, IP_Address columns, and Printer_ID is primary_key.
6 The users table has User_ID, Name, Email, Phone, Department, Role columns, and User_ID is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
consumables.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
maintenance_logs.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
print_jobs.Printer_ID to printers.Printer_ID.
printers.Manufacturer_ID to manufacturers.Manufacturer_ID.
print_jobs.User_ID to users.User_ID.
assistant:
{
  "entities": ["laser printer", "power consumption 800 watts", "warm-up phase 200 watts", "15-minute warm-up", "24-hour operation"],
  "relations": ["printer_to_power_specs (laser printer → power consumption specifications)", "operation_time_split (24 hours = 0.25 hours warm-up + 23.75 hours normal)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_consumption_for_printer_operation",
  "reasoning_type": "mathematical logic reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [800, 200, 15, 24],
  "units": {
    "power": "watts",
    "time": "hours",
    "energy": "kilowatt-hours (kWh)",
    "conversion": "15 minutes = 0.25 hours, 1000 watts = 1 kilowatt"
  },
  "required_tables": ["printers"],
  "required_fields": ["printers.Power_Consumption"]
}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Assuming that the wind speed at rain gauge No. 2 reaches 100 meters per second during a certain time period, calculate its impact on rainfall measurement and analyze the potential effects on data collection.
user:
The database information is as follows:First: RainGauge database has HistoricalRainfallAnalysis, RainGauge, RainfallData, RainfallWarningRule tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The HistoricalRainfallAnalysis table has Id, GaugeId, AnalysisTime, DataStartTime, DataEndTime, TotalRainfallMm, AverageRainfallIntensityMmH, MaxRainfallIntensityMmH, MinRainfallIntensityMmH, AnalysisResult columns, and Id is primary_key.
2 The RainGauge table has Id, GaugeModel, InstallationLocation, ManufactureDate, InstallationDate, Manufacturer, Status, Latitude, Longitude, ElevationMeters, Notes columns, and Id is primary_key.
3 The RainfallData table has Id, GaugeId, CollectionTime, RainfallMm, RainfallIntensityMmH, TemperatureCelsius, HumidityPercent, WindSpeedMps, WindDirectionDegrees, AtmosphericPressureHpa, Notes columns, and Id is primary_key.
4 The RainfallWarningRule table has Id, RuleName, ParameterType, ThresholdValue, ThresholdUnit, ConditionOperator, SeverityLevel, ActionType, RuleDescription, IsActive columns, and Id is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
assistant:
{
  "entities": ["rain gauge No. 2", "wind speed 100 meters per second"],
  "relations": ["gauge_to_data (rain gauge No. 2 → RainfallData.WindSpeedMps)", "wind_to_rainfall_impact (wind speed → measurement distortion)"],
  "intent": "analyze_impact_of_wind_speed_on_rainfall_measurement",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [100],
  "units": {
    "wind_speed": "meters per second (m/s)",
    "rainfall": "millimeters (mm) and mm/hour (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "100 m/s wind speed threshold for measurement distortion analysis"
  },
  "required_tables": ["RainGauge", "RainfallData", "HistoricalRainfallAnalysis"],
  "required_fields": [
    "RainGauge.Id", 
    "RainGauge.InstallationLocation",
    "RainGauge.ElevationMeters",
    "RainfallData.GaugeId",
    "RainfallData.WindSpeedMps",
    "RainfallData.RainfallMm",
    "RainfallData.RainfallIntensityMmH",
    "HistoricalRainfallAnalysis.TotalRainfallMm",
    "HistoricalRainfallAnalysis.AverageRainfallIntensityMmH"
  ]
}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Assuming a rice cooker with model RC-3003 (rated power 900W) is used in a plateau area at an altitude of 5000 meters, where the ambient temperature is -15°C and the boiling point drops to 85°C, calculate the time required to heat 2L of water from -15°C to 85°C (considering power reduction with increasing altitude, assuming power drops to 80% of the rated value, and additionally accounting for heat loss, with a heat loss coefficient of 20W/m²·°C and a rice cooker surface area of 0.12m²).
user:
The database information is as follows:First: rice_cooker database has maintenance_records, performance_tests, rice_cooker_info, usage_records tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The maintenance_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, maintenance_date, maintenance_type, maintenance_cost, maintenance_duration, replaced_parts, maintenance_notes, technician_name, technician_contact, next_maintenance_date columns, and id is primary_key.
2 The performance_tests table has id, rice_cooker_id, test_date, test_type, initial_temperature, final_temperature, time_to_boil, energy_consumption, rice_quality_score, water_evaporation_rate, test_notes columns, and id is primary_key.
3 The rice_cooker_info table has id, model, brand, capacity, power_rating, voltage_rating, weight, material, color, warranty_period, production_date, price columns, and id is primary_key.
4 The usage_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, start_time, end_time, duration, temperature_setting, actual_max_temperature, energy_consumption, rice_type, rice_quantity, water_quantity columns, and id is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
maintenance_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
performance_tests.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
usage_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
assistant:
{
  "entities": [
    "rice cooker model RC-3003", 
    "rated power 900W", 
    "altitude 5000 meters", 
    "ambient temperature -15°C", 
    "boiling point 85°C", 
    "water volume 2L", 
    "power reduction 80%", 
    "heat loss coefficient 20W/m²·°C", 
    "rice cooker surface area 0.12m²"
  ],
  "relations": [
    "model_to_specs (RC-3003 → rice_cooker_info.power_rating)",
    "temperature_difference (ΔT=100°C, from -15°C to 85°C)",
    "power_adjustment (900W * 0.8 = 720W effective power at altitude)",
    "heat_loss (20W/m²·°C * 0.12m² * 100°C = 240W heat dissipation)"
  ],
  "intent": "calculate_heating_time_with_environmental_factors",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [
    900, 5000, -15, 85, 2, 0.8, 20, 0.12
  ],
  "units": {
    "power": "W (Watts)",
    "altitude": "m (meters)",
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "volume": "L (Liters)",
    "heat_loss_coefficient": "W/m²·°C",
    "surface_area": "m² (Square meters)",
    "time": "s (Seconds, derived from calculations)"
  },
  "required_tables": [
    "rice_cooker_info"
  ],
  "required_fields": [
    "rice_cooker_info.model",
    "rice_cooker_info.power_rating"
  ]
}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Constructing a rice cooker health index: EXP(-maintenance cost/price)×(1+LN(usage frequency))×coefficient of variation for rice quality score and forecasting trends by quarter.
user:
The database information is as follows:First: rice_cooker database has maintenance_records, performance_tests, rice_cooker_info, usage_records tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The maintenance_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, maintenance_date, maintenance_type, maintenance_cost, maintenance_duration, replaced_parts, maintenance_notes, technician_name, technician_contact, next_maintenance_date columns, and id is primary_key.
2 The performance_tests table has id, rice_cooker_id, test_date, test_type, initial_temperature, final_temperature, time_to_boil, energy_consumption, rice_quality_score, water_evaporation_rate, test_notes columns, and id is primary_key.
3 The rice_cooker_info table has id, model, brand, capacity, power_rating, voltage_rating, weight, material, color, warranty_period, production_date, price columns, and id is primary_key.
4 The usage_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, start_time, end_time, duration, temperature_setting, actual_max_temperature, energy_consumption, rice_type, rice_quantity, water_quantity columns, and id is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
maintenance_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
performance_tests.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
usage_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
assistant:
{
  "entities": ["rice cooker", "maintenance cost", "rice cooker price", "usage frequency", "rice quality score"],
  "relations": [
    "rice_cooker_to_maintenance_cost (rice_cooker_id → maintenance_records.maintenance_cost)",
    "rice_cooker_to_price (rice_cooker_id → rice_cooker_info.price)",
    "rice_cooker_to_usage_frequency (rice_cooker_id → usage_records.count)",
    "rice_cooker_to_rice_quality_score (rice_cooker_id → performance_tests.rice_quality_score)"
  ],
  "intent": "calculate_health_index_and_forecast_trends",
  "reasoning_type": "mathematical logic reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [],
  "units": {
    "maintenance_cost": "currency (e.g., USD)",
    "price": "currency (e.g., USD)",
    "usage_frequency": "count per quarter (from usage_records)",
    "rice_quality_score": "numerical score (unitless, from performance_tests)",
    "coefficient_of_variation": "unitless (standard deviation/mean of rice_quality_score)"
  },
  "required_tables": [
    "maintenance_records",
    "rice_cooker_info",
    "usage_records",
    "performance_tests"
  ],
  "required_fields": [
    "maintenance_records.rice_cooker_id",
    "maintenance_records.maintenance_cost",
    "rice_cooker_info.id",
    "rice_cooker_info.price",
    "usage_records.rice_cooker_id",
    "usage_records.start_time",
    "performance_tests.rice_cooker_id",
    "performance_tests.rice_quality_score"
  ]
}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",
    "air_conditioner_info.energy_efficiency_ratio",
    "energy_consumption.power_consumption_watts",
    "energy_consumption.energy_consumption_kwh"
  ]
}
The question of user is as follows:
Assuming cooking in a superfluid helium environment (temperature 2K), calculate the enhancement effect of quantum vortices on thermal conduction (vortex density n=10^16/m^5, thermal conductivity k=κn^6/m).
user:
The database information is as follows:First: rice_cooker database has maintenance_records, performance_tests, rice_cooker_info, usage_records tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The maintenance_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, maintenance_date, maintenance_type, maintenance_cost, maintenance_duration, replaced_parts, maintenance_notes, technician_name, technician_contact, next_maintenance_date columns, and id is primary_key.
2 The performance_tests table has id, rice_cooker_id, test_date, test_type, initial_temperature, final_temperature, time_to_boil, energy_consumption, rice_quality_score, water_evaporation_rate, test_notes columns, and id is primary_key.
3 The rice_cooker_info table has id, model, brand, capacity, power_rating, voltage_rating, weight, material, color, warranty_period, production_date, price columns, and id is primary_key.
4 The usage_records table has id, rice_cooker_id, start_time, end_time, duration, temperature_setting, actual_max_temperature, energy_consumption, rice_type, rice_quantity, water_quantity columns, and id is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
maintenance_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
performance_tests.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.
usage_records.rice_cooker_id to rice_cooker_info.rice_cooker_id.

  },

}

Entity refers to the key information asked by the user, such as the query object; Relationship refers to the relationship between entities; Intent is the intention of the user's query; Reasoning type is divided into: physical knowledge reasoning, mathematical logic reasoning, common sense understanding reasoning, ideal hypothesis reasoning. Numerical value refers to the specific parameter value requested by that query; Unit refers to the unit conversion formula, unit type, unit value, etc. for the calculation of that question. I will give you a user's natural language question, please answer me in Json format and The key value of your json should be qualified as entities, relations, intent, reasoning_type, numerical_values, units, required_tables, and required_fields. this is example:
{
  "entities": ["air conditioner model AC-1234", "indoor temperature 30°C", "target temperature 25°C"],
  "relations": ["model_to_specs (AC-1234 → technical specifications)", "temperature_difference (ΔT=5°C)"],
  "intent": "calculate_energy_required_for_cooling",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 25],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C (Celsius)",
    "energy": "kWh (implied by database schema)",
    "conversion": "ΔT = 5°C (temperature differential)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["air_conditioner_info", "energy_consumption"],
  "required_fields": [
    "air_conditioner_info.model", 
    "air_conditioner_info.cooling_capacity_btu",

  ]

The question of user is as follows:
If the temperature recorded by Water Quality Monitor No. 1 is 30 degrees Celsius, calculate the heat required to heat 1 liter of water from 20 degrees Celsius to 30 degrees Celsius based on the specific heat capacity of water. The known specific heat capacity of water is 4.18 J/g·°C, and the density of water is 1 g/mL.
user:
The database information is as follows:First: WaterQualityMonitor database has WaterQualityData, WaterQualityMonitor, WaterQualityWarningRule, WaterQualityWarningTriggerRecord tables.
Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The WaterQualityData table has Id, MonitorId, CollectionTime, PHValue, DissolvedOxygenMgL, TurbidityNTU, TemperatureCelsius, ConductivityUsCm, TotalDissolvedSolidsMgL, AmmoniaNitrogenMgL, NitrateNitrogenMgL, Notes columns, and Id is primary_key.
2 The WaterQualityMonitor table has Id, MonitorModel, InstallationLocation, ManufactureDate, InstallationDate, Manufacturer, Status, Latitude, Longitude, WaterSourceType, Notes columns, and Id is primary_key.
3 The WaterQualityWarningRule table has Id, RuleName, ParameterType, ThresholdValue, ThresholdUnit, ConditionOperator, SeverityLevel, ActionType, RuleDescription, IsActive columns, and Id is primary_key.
4 The WaterQualityWarningTriggerRecord table has Id, MonitorId, RuleId, TriggerTime, TriggerValue, TriggerUnit, SeverityLevel, ActionTaken, IsFalseAlarm, TriggerDescription columns, and Id is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:

{
  "entities": ["Water Quality Monitor No. 1", "1 liter of water", "initial temperature 20°C", "final temperature 30°C", "specific heat capacity 4.18 J/g·°C", "density of water 1 g/mL"],
  "relations": [
    "monitor_to_temperature (Monitor No. 1 → 30°C)",
    "volume_to_mass_conversion (1 liter → 1000g via density)",
    "heat_calculation (Q = mass × specific heat × ΔT)"
  ],
  "intent": "calculate_heat_required_for_water_heating",
  "reasoning_type": "physical knowledge reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [30, 20, 1, 4.18, 1],
  "units": {
    "temperature": "°C",
    "volume": "liter (convert to milliliters: 1000 mL)",
    "mass": "grams (1 g/mL × 1000 mL = 1000g)",
    "specific_heat": "J/g·°C",
    "energy": "Joules (J)"
  },
  "required_tables": ["WaterQualityData"],
  "required_fields": [
    "WaterQualityData.MonitorId",
    "WaterQualityData.TemperatureCelsius"
  ]
}

Second: below are columns of table, primary_keys of table:
1 The maintenance_records table has Record_ID, Pump_ID, Maintenance_Date, Maintenance_Type, Description, Technician, Cost columns, and Record_ID is primary_key.
2 The pump_specifications table has Spec_ID, Pump_ID, Flow_Rate, Head, Power, Voltage, Current, Efficiency columns, and Spec_ID is primary_key.
3 The pumps table has Pump_ID, Model_Number, Manufacturer, Purchase_Date, Warranty_Period, Location, Status columns, and Pump_ID is primary_key.
4 The usage_records table has Ssage_ID, pump_ID, User_ID, Start_Time, End_Time, Usage_Hours, Notes columns, and Ssage_ID is primary_key.
5 The users table has User_ID, Username, Password, Email, Phone, Role columns, and User_ID is primary_key.
Third: below are foreign_keys of tables:
maintenance_records.Pump_ID to pump_specifications.Pump_ID.
pump_specifications.Pump_ID to pumps.Pump_ID.
usage_records.pump_ID to pumps.pump_ID.
usage_records.User_ID to users.User_ID.

{
  "entities": ["pump", "flow rate 1000 m³/h", "head 1000 meters", "power 10,000 kW", "30 days"],
  "relations": [
    "pump_to_specifications (pump → pump_specifications)", 
    "time_conversion (30 days → 720 hours)", 
    "energy_consumption (power × usage hours)", 
    "cost_calculation (energy × electricity_rate)"
  ],
  "intent": "calculate_electricity_cost_for_pump_operation",
  "reasoning_type": "mathematical_logic_reasoning",
  "numerical_values": [1000, 1000, 10000, 30],
  "units": {
    "flow_rate": "m³/h (cubic meters per hour)",
    "head": "meters",
    "power": "kW (kilowatts)",
    "time": "days (converted to hours)",
    "conversion": "1 day = 24 hours → 30 days = 720 hours",
    "energy": "kWh (kilowatt-hours = kW × hours)"
  },
  "required_tables": [
    "pump_specifications", 
    "usage_records", 
    "pumps"
  ],
  "required_fields": [
    "pump_specifications.Power", 
    "usage_records.Usage_Hours", 
    "pumps.Pump_ID"
  ]
}
